ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to analyze global infrastructure.
This class was ridiculous, a whole semester later and I still have no idea what globalization space means. This was supplemented by instruction on other made up.

The built environment includes a lot more than we think of, including repeated forms such as the Free Trade Zone, infrastructural networks, and financial systems. It is programmed in ways that benefit certain groups over others and replicate/solidify patterns of inequality. The course seeks possible alternatives that demand global solidarity instead of continued marginalization.
I learned about our globalized world
Quite literally nothing of value.
Knowledge on the world around me and the interconnectedness of all things around the world.
Understanding of the conceptual frameworks that ground globalization.

I learned about the structures, global dynamics, and systems of power that continue to exploit and engender oppression and various forms of structural and personal violence. This course teaches you how spatial dynamics exemplify these structures through specific examples of destruction, the built environment from airports to golf courses, and the manners in which globalization is spatialized through areas of different sovereignties, nation states, and the built landscape. Really imaginative / abstracted networks and visualizations of the flows of infrastructure and how this contributes to capitalizing and globalizing.

I gained a remarkable breadth of understanding in this course.  Approaching the complexity of our global community through a variety of lenses and angles was overwhelming, but necessary.  I am excited to continue learning with the skills and avenues of thinking I developed in this course.
I gained a broad base of knowledge on many topics related to the modern global world, such as transportation, tourism, networks, and more.
I learned so much about the interconnectivity of global systems, and how to think about architecture as more of a framework, beyond the scale of just buildings.
I learned a lot about spaciality and global interplays.
Critical thinking about global systems and structures.
interconnectedness

To be honest, I'm not sure exactly what I learned in this course. It was essentially a think tank covering a variety of concepts relating to architecture and globalization. I do think the sections were valuable in discussing world events and trends.
g
I learned how to work with a team to take different approaches to the same problem.
I learned about the effects of capitalism and colonization on globalization
Interdisciplinary analysis? It was a little hard at times to discern the teaching goals of this course. It felt more like a lecture series than something that aimed to engage students.
I learned a lot about the ways that the world is connected. This class is very very abstract, which can be confusing, but it made sense when learning why we were learning about it.
This class is key to thinking outside the box and really push your pre-exisitng understandings of the world and of globalization.
Broad understanding of the way world systems are connected via physical infrastructure, trade, policy, development.
understanding contemporary capitalism from a global perspective.
knowlddge on architecture

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Course is very easy, good fifth class to add for a humanities credit. Weakness is that is that it is sometimes quite boring.
very interesting lectures!

Lectures could feel completely random at times and a bit far fetched. There was not much student engagement in lecture and it was distracting to see people on their phones/computers. However, there were other weeks when the readings and lectures were very insightful.
The choice of a topic and group for the final project can make the class very interesting and rewarding if you chose well, so it is important to self motivate.

strengths: the class provided some really interesting insight and information about globalization. I LOVED how prof. easterling would spend the last 15 minutes of lecture soliciting questions. I was always excited to come to class and learn something new from such a a great professor. 
weaknesses: structure of the assignments. My group had some group members who weren't pulling their weight and that detracted from the experience. I would have preferred doing it individually, or with one partner. Also, if the group structure stayed, I would have preferred to have a rough draft due about two weeks before the final, with a meeting with the TA to follow, to make sure that the group was on track.
There is absolutely no value or substance to this class whatsoever. It is merely a platform for the radical professor to pontificate against capitalism and the United States.

Great readings
Really disorienting and confusing lectures that often didn't touch on the same topics as the week's readings
It was great at forcing students to work together.
More concrete takeaways from each lesson
I think the course material is quite interesting, but extremely theoretical and could have benefitted from more discussions of concrete examples.

The lectures were really not my style, it was basically throwing out many examples, dates, and quick information that could be used to contextualize and draw broader conclusions about the spatial manifestations of globalization. The lecture style was not super engaging but the readings were really helpful with elaborating on some of the course themes where it was a little difficult to ascertain them from the lectures. The group project was definitely the best part and the main strength of the course in that it allows people to gear their learning in the course toward something they're really interested in. The course could really be improved by having each student only present for 1 section meeting, and having the other ones be more organized by the teaching fellow so they are a little more productive or engaging.
Sometimes lecture could go a bit quickly, but that is the nature I think.  I would get a bit overwhelmed and not know what questions I had, or how to ask them.

The lectures could get a bit dry at some points. The professor jumps from topic to topic very quickly and I feel that it is often hard to follow along. However, the discussions during section are quite interesting and we got to talk about some applications of the concepts we learned about in class.

Lectures are really interesting and enjoyable, but I found the course not be very organized. I also think that putting so much weight on a group project is quite challenging in a college context, especially because we had to pick our groups from sections. Everyone works differently and has different expectations for their work, and it inevitably led to really unequal work dynamics within groups.
section was good, lecture was not
Keller is clearly very knowledgeable about the topic and an expert in the field. However, lectures were not the most engaging.
The lectures weren't engaging enough. The variety of topics would make it so if i wasn't interested during one week i could during the next.
pretty confusing topic
I think this course was interesting and not difficult, but I wouldn't say I learned a lot of content. I also don't think the intention is to teach content, though, so just know that going into it.
g

-Easy workload
Interesting lectures and topics 
Terrible, obfuscating, nebulous reading assignments. 
Sections were sometimes dull
Better assignments.
Lectures were good but the level of engagement between most people in class was very low.

Strengths: The readings each week were all very interesting and made for dynamic class discussions

Weaknesses: Oftentimes I felt that the class was a bit too abstract and didn't offer enough concrete definitions and examples that could be used to apply the theory to real life events and solutions

Pretty abstract, no testable knowledge--kinda like a ted talk or youtube video that provokes bigger thought rather than just teaching you one thing. This could be a strength or a weakness for you, depending on your style of learning/goals for taking the course.
the assignments could be more clear and more hands on rather than very up in the air.

This course covered many topics and touched on many things that we do not talk about in many other classes at Yale. I think some times the level of analysis was overly complex and wordy in a way that makes it almost more difficult to "imagine planetary solutions" as we were often prompted to do. The readings were mostly engaging and offered often a more palatable level of analysis.
very hard to engage w lectures

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, its a good gut class for a humanities credit with minimal work.

If you are a STEM student looking for a humanities class, I would recommend this class. It is a great humanities class that really lets you take your own path and interpretations of Keller's lectures. Make sure you take this class with friends for the final project!
yes! chill and engaging. The topic matter is also very relevant to everyday life!

Not if you're expecting to "be taught" anything directly or to learn discrete skills or material. It's a good class for thinking about things that we are not used to questioning, if you allow yourself patience and curiosity.
Yes! I would definitely recommend. It gives a great overview of globalization with some really fascinating insights and lessons. It isn't overly demanding and is really engaging for a lecture class.
Avoid at all costs.
No  just download the syllabus and do the readings on your own

Maybe; the project was super interesting and discussion section helped me to understand and articulate some of the ideas. However, I didnt find lectures very compelling and they seemed unnecessarily convoluted.
Sure - pretty solid 5th course to add to a workload because it connects to both STEM and humanities courses in a cool current events manner

I would recommend this course to you if you are a global or architecture or urban major and need to take it for the major. It would not be my first choice to do again, and only take this course if you like group projects since the last two thirds of the course are geared around one group project. You can definitely learn a lot from the readings if you engage with them but oftentimes there were too many to get through in a given week for it to be manageable as a fifth class.
Absolutely.  Professor Easterling is wonderful and the TF's are very helpful.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student if they wish to learn very broadly about the structure of the modern world and how it came to be.

Yes, overall I would! I loved the lectures and Professor Easterling's choices for readings. I just think I enjoyed it so much because I came in already really eager about the material, not necessarily because the course was highly engaging.
yes, learn tangible life things
Yes if they are really interested in architecture and urban studies. Otherwise, they may find other classes more engaging.

For an urban studies, architecture, global, or very open-minded person, yes. This class hit some really interesting topics and philosophies i would never have considerered or heard about from other classes.
no
I would recommend this course as a gut. It doesn't cover much actual content, but that's not necessarily the intention of the course. Discussion section was often interesting.
g
If you are looking for a holistic course on infrastructure, capitalism and the effects of an internet society
Yes, it is a very cool cross-reference between subjects.

This course is what you make it. If you want to put in little effort, you might find it not to be a good use of your time. If you're interested in doing the readings, attending lectures, and actively thinking through topics in section, I'd recommend.

yes. its a good way to understand architectures position in the global setting without necessarily designing buildings only. its good to think outside of architecture but approach it from a holistic point of view.
no, it wasn't very constructive learning enviornment and the content was extremely confusing and not explained well
